<?php

namespace App\Http\Controllers;

use App\Models\BusinessProcessProcess;
use App\Models\BusinessProcessCore;
use App\Models\BusinessProcessActivity;
use App\Traits\HtmlParser;
use Illuminate\Http\Request;
use Inertia\Inertia;
use Inertia\Response;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Auth;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\DB;
use Illuminate\Http\RedirectResponse;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Log;
use Illuminate\Foundation\Auth\Access\AuthorizesRequests;

class ProcessCoreController extends Controller
{
    use HtmlParser, AuthorizesRequests;

    public function index(BusinessProcessProcess $process): Response
    {
        // Eager load the category for breadcrumbs
        $process->load('category');

        // Retrieve cores related to the specific process
        // and belonging to the authenticated user, then paginate.
        $cores = $process->cores() // Access the HasMany relationship
            ->where('user_id', Auth::id()) // Filter by the current user
            ->withCount('activities') // Add activities count
            ->orderBy('updated_at', 'desc')
            ->paginate(10);

        // Transform cores to diagrams for frontend compatibility
        $cores->getCollection()->transform(function ($core) {
            $coreArray = $core->toArray();
            return $coreArray;
        });

        // The $process model instance is already available.
        // We pass the filtered and paginated $cores to the view.
        return Inertia::render('business-processes/cores/index', [
            'process' => $process,
            'cores' => $cores,
        ]);
    }

    public function store(Request $request, BusinessProcessProcess $process): RedirectResponse
    {
        // Check if user can create cores
        $this->authorize('create', BusinessProcessCore::class);

        $validatedData = $request->validate([
            'name' => 'required|string|max:255',
            'description' => 'nullable|string',
            'version' => 'nullable|string|max:10',
        ]);

        $core = $process->cores()->create([
            'name' => $validatedData['name'],
            'description' => $validatedData['description'],
            'version' => $validatedData['version'] ?? '1.0',
            'owner' => Auth::user()->name, // Set authenticated user as owner
            'status' => 0,     // Default status (e.g., Draft)
            'user_id' => Auth::id()
        ]);

        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$process->id, $core->id])->with('success', 'Core created successfully.');
    }

    public function show(Request $request, BusinessProcessCore $core): Response
    {
        // Check if user can view this core
        $this->authorize('view', $core);

        // Eager load the process, user, and category relationships
        $core->load(['process.category', 'user']);

        // Paginate activities (50 per page) ordered by position
        // Include Blueprint relationships for activity integration with optimized queries
        $activities = $core->activities()
            ->with(['blueprint'])
            ->orderBy('position')
            ->paginate(50);

        // Generate Mermaid code from all activities (not paginated for visualization)
        // Cache the Mermaid code for better performance
        $cacheKey = "core_mermaid_{$core->id}_{$core->updated_at->timestamp}";
        $generatedMermaidCode = cache()->remember($cacheKey, 3600, function () use ($core) {
            // For now, return empty string - can implement mermaid generation later
            return '';
        });

        // Transform core to diagram for frontend compatibility
        $coreArray = $core->toArray();

        return Inertia::render('business-processes/cores/show', [
            'core' => $coreArray,
            'activities' => $activities,
            'generatedMermaidCode' => $generatedMermaidCode,
        ]);
    }

    public function update(Request $request, BusinessProcessCore $core): RedirectResponse
    {
        // Check if user can update this core
        $this->authorize('update', $core);

        $validatedData = $request->validate([
            'name' => 'required|string|max:255',
            'description' => 'nullable|string',
            'owner' => 'required|string|max:255',
            'status' => 'required|integer|in:0,1,2', // Assuming 0: Draft, 1: Active, 2: Archived
        ]);

        $core->update($validatedData);

        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$core->process->id, $core->id])->with('success', 'Core updated successfully.');
    }

    public function destroy(BusinessProcessCore $core): RedirectResponse
    {
        // Check if user can delete this core
        $this->authorize('delete', $core);

        $processId = $core->business_process_id;
        $coreName = $core->name;

        // Delete the core (activities will be cascade deleted due to foreign key constraint)
        $core->delete();

        // Redirect back to the process cores index with success message
        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.index', $processId)
            ->with('success', 'Core "' . $coreName . '" and all its activities have been deleted successfully.');
    }

    public function storeActivity(Request $request, BusinessProcessProcess $process, BusinessProcessCore $core): RedirectResponse
    {
        if ($core->business_process_id !== $process->id) {
            abort(404); // Or handle as a validation error
        }

        // Check if user can view/modify this core (implicitly allows creating activities)
        $this->authorize('update', $core);

        // Check for duplicate activity name first
        $existingActivity = $core->activities()->where('name', $request->input('name'))->first();
        if ($existingActivity) {
            return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$process->id, $core->id])
                ->with('error', 'An activity with this name already exists in this core. Please choose a different name.');
        }

        $validated = $request->validate([
            'name' => 'required|string|max:255',
            'responsible' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'accountable' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'consulted' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'informed' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
        ]);

        $maxPosition = $core->activities()->max('position');
        $newPosition = ($maxPosition === null) ? 1 : $maxPosition + 1;

        $activityData = $validated + [
            'position' => $newPosition,
        ];

        $core->activities()->create($activityData);

        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$process->id, $core->id])->with('success', 'Activity created successfully.');
    }

    // New method to update an existing activity
    public function updateActivity(Request $request, BusinessProcessActivity $activity): RedirectResponse
    {
        // Load the core relationship and check authorization
        $activity->load('core');
        $this->authorize('update', $activity);

        // Check for duplicate activity name first (excluding current activity)
        $existingActivity = $activity->core->activities()
            ->where('name', $request->input('name'))
            ->where('id', '!=', $activity->id)
            ->first();

        if ($existingActivity) {
            return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$activity->core->process->id, $activity->core->id])
                ->with('error', 'An activity with this name already exists in this core. Please choose a different name.');
        }

        $validatedData = $request->validate([
            'name' => 'required|string|max:255',
            'responsible' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'accountable' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'consulted' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'informed' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
        ]);

        $activity->update($validatedData);

        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$activity->core->process->id, $activity->core->id])->with('success', 'Activity updated successfully.');
    }

    public function deleteActivity(BusinessProcessActivity $activity): RedirectResponse
    {
        // Load the core relationship and check authorization
        $activity->load('core');
        $this->authorize('delete', $activity);

        $coreId = $activity->business_process_core_id;
        $processId = $activity->core->business_process_id;
        $activityName = $activity->name;

        $activity->delete();

        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$processId, $coreId])
            ->with('success', 'Activity "' . $activityName . '" has been deleted successfully.');
    }

    public function reorderActivities(Request $request, BusinessProcessProcess $process, BusinessProcessCore $core): RedirectResponse
    {
        $this->authorize('update', $core);

        $validated = $request->validate([
            'activities' => 'required|array',
            'activities.*.id' => 'required|exists:business_process_activities,id',
            'activities.*.order' => 'required|integer|min:1', // Accept 'order' for compatibility with ProcessActivitiesCard
        ]);

        try {
            DB::transaction(function () use ($validated, $core) {
                foreach ($validated['activities'] as $activityData) {
                    // Verify that the activity belongs to this core
                    $activity = $core->activities()
                        ->where('id', $activityData['id'])
                        ->first();

                    if ($activity) {
                        $activity->update(['position' => $activityData['order']]); // Map 'order' to 'position'
                    }
                }
            });

            Log::info('Activities reordered successfully for core ID: ' . $core->id, [
                'core_id' => $core->id,
                'user_id' => Auth::id(),
                'reordered_activities' => $validated['activities'],
            ]);

            return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$core->process->id, $core->id])
                ->with('success', 'Activities reordered successfully.');
        } catch (\Exception $e) {
            Log::error('Failed to reorder activities for core ID: ' . $core->id, [
                'error' => $e->getMessage(),
                'trace' => $e->getTraceAsString(),
                'user_id' => Auth::id(),
            ]);

            return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$core->process->id, $core->id])
                ->with('error', 'Failed to reorder activities. Please try again.');
        }
    }
}

<?php

namespace App\Traits;

use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Log;
use DOMDocument;
use DOMXPath;

trait HtmlParser
{
    /**
     * Parses HTML content to extract a list of activities with their RACI assignments.
     *
     * @param string $htmlContent The HTML content to parse.
     * @return array A list of activities, where each activity is an associative array.
     *               Example structure:
     *               [
     *                   'name' => 'Activity Name',
     *                   'position' => 1,
     *                   'current_future' => 0, // 0 for Current, 1 for Future
     *                   'responsible' => 'Person R',
     *                   'accountable' => 'Person A',
     *                   'consulted' => 'Person C',
     *                   'informed' => 'Person I',
     *                   'process_link' => null,
     *                   'description' => null,
     *                   'type' => null,
     *               ]
     */
    public function parseHtmlToActivities(string $htmlContent): array
    {
        Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Starting HTML parsing');

        $activities = [];
        $position = 0;

        // Create a DOMDocument and load the HTML
        $dom = new DOMDocument();

        // Suppress warnings for malformed HTML
        libxml_use_internal_errors(true);

        // Load HTML content
        $dom->loadHTML($htmlContent, LIBXML_HTML_NOIMPLIED | LIBXML_HTML_NODEFDTD);

        // Clear libxml errors
        libxml_clear_errors();

        $xpath = new DOMXPath($dom);

        // Find all step-box elements (activities)
        $stepBoxes = $xpath->query("//div[contains(@class, 'step-box')]");

        Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Found step boxes', ['count' => $stepBoxes->length]);

        foreach ($stepBoxes as $stepBox) {
            $position++;

            // Extract activity name from step-title
            $titleNodes = $xpath->query(".//div[contains(@class, 'step-title')]", $stepBox);
            $activityName = $titleNodes->length > 0 ? trim($titleNodes->item(0)->textContent) : '';

            // Extract description from step-desc
            $descNodes = $xpath->query(".//div[contains(@class, 'step-desc')]", $stepBox);
            $description = $descNodes->length > 0 ? trim($descNodes->item(0)->textContent) : null;

            // Extract RACI information from raci class
            $raciNodes = $xpath->query(".//div[contains(@class, 'raci')]", $stepBox);
            $raciText = $raciNodes->length > 0 ? trim($raciNodes->item(0)->textContent) : '';

            Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Processing activity', [
                'position' => $position,
                'name' => $activityName,
                'description' => $description,
                'raci_text' => $raciText
            ]);

            // Skip if no activity name
            if (empty($activityName)) {
                Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Skipping activity with empty name');
                continue;
            }

            // Initialize activity data
            $activityData = [
                'name' => $activityName,
                'position' => $position,
                'current_future' => 0, // Default to current
                'responsible' => null,
                'accountable' => null,
                'consulted' => null,
                'informed' => null,
                'process_link' => null,
                'description' => $description,
                'type' => null,
            ];

            // Parse RACI information
            if (!empty($raciText)) {
                $activityData = $this->parseRaciFromText($raciText, $activityData);
            }

            Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Final activity data', ['data' => $activityData]);
            $activities[] = $activityData;
        }

        Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Parsing complete. Total activities parsed:', ['count' => count($activities)]);
        return $activities;
    }

    /**
     * Parse RACI information from text like "R: Julia | A: Vipul | C: Dale"
     *
     * @param string $raciText The RACI text to parse
     * @param array $activityData The activity data array to update
     * @return array Updated activity data with RACI assignments
     */
    private function parseRaciFromText(string $raciText, array $activityData): array
    {
        Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Parsing RACI text', ['text' => $raciText]);

        // Handle special case for handoff text
        if (strpos($raciText, 'Handoff to') !== false) {
            Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Skipping handoff text');
            return $activityData;
        }

        // Split by pipe (|) to get individual RACI assignments
        $raciParts = explode('|', $raciText);

        foreach ($raciParts as $part) {
            $part = trim($part);

            // Match pattern like "R: Julia" or "A: Vipul"
            if (preg_match('/^([RACI])\s*:\s*(.+)$/i', $part, $matches)) {
                $role = strtoupper(trim($matches[1]));
                $person = trim($matches[2]);

                // Skip N/A assignments
                if (strtoupper($person) === 'N/A') {
                    continue;
                }

                Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Found RACI assignment', ['role' => $role, 'person' => $person]);

                switch ($role) {
                    case 'R':
                        $activityData['responsible'] = $person;
                        break;
                    case 'A':
                        $activityData['accountable'] = $person;
                        break;
                    case 'C':
                        $activityData['consulted'] = $person;
                        break;
                    case 'I':
                        $activityData['informed'] = $person;
                        break;
                }
            }
        }

        return $activityData;
    }
}

<?php

namespace App\Models;

use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Factories\HasFactory;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Model;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Relations\BelongsTo;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Relations\HasMany;

class BusinessProcessContent extends Model
{
    use HasFactory;

    protected $fillable = [
        'business_process_core_id',
        'type',
        'title',
        'created_by',
        'updated_by',
        'is_archived',
        'archived_date',
        'archived_by'
    ];

    protected $casts = [
        'business_process_core_id' => 'integer',
        'created_by' => 'integer',
        'updated_by' => 'integer',
        'archived_by' => 'integer',
        'is_archived' => 'boolean',
        'archived_date' => 'datetime',
        'created_at' => 'datetime:M j, Y - H:i:s',
        'updated_at' => 'datetime:M j, Y - H:i:s',
    ];

    public function core(): BelongsTo
    {
        return $this->belongsTo(BusinessProcessCore::class, 'business_process_core_id');
    }

    public function creator(): BelongsTo
    {
        return $this->belongsTo(User::class, 'created_by');
    }

    public function updater(): BelongsTo
    {
        return $this->belongsTo(User::class, 'updated_by');
    }

    public function archiver(): BelongsTo
    {
        return $this->belongsTo(User::class, 'archived_by');
    }

    public function versions(): HasMany
    {
        return $this->hasMany(BusinessProcessContentVersion::class, 'content_id');
    }

    public function getCurrentVersion()
    {
        return $this->versions()->where('status', 'current')->first();
    }

    public function getLatestVersion()
    {
        return $this->versions()->orderBy('version_number', 'desc')->first();
    }

    /**
     * Get versions sorted by status priority and version number.
     * Order: Current (if any), Future (if any), then all Draft (newest to oldest)
     */
    public function getSortedVersions()
    {
        return $this->versions()
            ->with(['creator'])
            ->get()
            ->sort(function ($a, $b) {
                // Define status priority: Current=3, Archived=2, Draft=1
                $statusPriority = [
                    'current' => 3,  // Current gets highest priority
                    'archived' => 2, // Archived gets second priority (like Future in SOP)
                    'draft' => 1,    // Draft gets lowest priority (like WIP in SOP)
                ];

                $aPriority = $statusPriority[$a->status] ?? 0;
                $bPriority = $statusPriority[$b->status] ?? 0;

                // First sort by status priority (higher priority first)
                if ($aPriority !== $bPriority) {
                    return $bPriority - $aPriority;
                }

                // Within same status, sort by version number (newest first)
                return (float)$b->version_number - (float)$a->version_number;
            })
            ->values(); // Reset array keys
    }

    public function getNextVersionNumber(): int
    {
        $maxVersion = $this->versions()->max('version_number');
        return ((int)$maxVersion ?? 0) + 1;
    }
}

Perfect! Now I have all the context I need. Based on my analysis, here's what I understand:

1. **Current Architecture**: 
   - There's already an HtmlImportDialog component that's referenced but seems to be for legacy diagram import (using `diagrams.parse-html` route)
   - The system has a sophisticated 4-level architecture: Process â†’ Core â†’ Activities â†’ Blueprints
   - The RACI tab is handled by `RaciTabContent` which uses `BusinessProcessActivitiesCard`
   - There's already an HtmlParser trait in the backend that can parse HTML and extract activities
   - Visual Diagram content is stored in the `BusinessProcessContent` system with versioning

2. **User Requirements**:
   - Add an "Import HTML" button to the RACI tab (next to "Add Activity")
   - Parse HTML content to extract Categories (class="section-header") and Activities (step-box)
   - Create RACI entries with relationships between categories and activities
   - Override all existing RACI activities in the core process
   - Store the HTML as "Visual Diagram" content
   - Keep Visual Diagram content synced when RACI activities change

3. **Sample HTML Structure**:
   - `.process-section` contains categories and activities
   - `.section-header` defines category names  
   - `.step-box` contains individual activities
   - `.step-title` has activity names
   - `.step-desc` has descriptions
   - `.raci` has RACI assignments in format "R: Person | A: Person | C: Person"

input.plan:
# HTML Import Implementation Plan for RACI Tab ## Overview Add an "Import HTML" button to the RACI tab that will parse HTML content, extract activity categories and RACI data, create/update the RACI matrix, and store the HTML as Visual Diagram content. ## Implementation Steps ### 1. Backend Updates **Enhance HtmlParser Trait** (`app/Traits/HtmlParser.php`) - Add new method `parseHtmlToActivitiesWithCategories()` to extract both categories and activities - Parse `.section-header` elements for category names - Associate activities with their parent categories - Handle the improved HTML structure from the sample **Update ProcessCoreController** (`app/Http/Controllers/ProcessCoreController.php`) - Add new method `importHtmlToRaci()` to handle RACI-specific HTML import - Implement logic to: - Clear existing activities (override functionality) - Create new activities with category associations - Store HTML content as Visual Diagram content in BusinessProcessContent system - Return success/error responses **Add New Route** (`routes/web.php`) - Add route: `POST /business-processes/{process}/cores/{core}/import-html-raci` ### 2. Database Considerations **Activity Categories** - Determine if we need a new `activity_category` field in `business_process_activities` table - Or use existing relationship structures to associate activities with categories **Visual Diagram Storage** - Utilize existing `BusinessProcessContent` system with type `visual_diagram` - Store imported HTML as versioned content ### 3. Frontend Updates **Update BusinessProcessActivitiesCard** (`resources/js/components/business-processes/business-process-activities-card.tsx`) - Add "Import HTML" button next to "Add Activity" button - Add state management for import dialog - Import and integrate the existing `HtmlImportDialog` component - Update the dialog to use the new RACI import endpoint **Enhance HtmlImportDialog** (`resources/js/components/diagrams/html-import-dialog.tsx`) - Modify to support both legacy diagram import and new RACI import modes - Add prop to specify import type (`raci` vs `diagram`) - Update API calls to use appropriate endpoint based on mode - Update warning text for RACI override functionality **Update VisualTabContent** (`resources/js/pages/business-processes/cores/partials/visual-tab-content.tsx`) - Replace placeholder with actual visual diagram content display - Show imported HTML content when available - Add sync indicator when RACI changes affect visual content ### 4. Enhanced HTML Parsing Logic **Category Extraction** - Parse `.section-header` elements to identify process categories - Extract category names and associate with following activities - Handle multiple categories within single HTML document **Activity Processing** - Enhanced parsing of `.step-box` elements within category sections - Extract `.step-title`, `.step-desc`, and `.raci` content - Maintain position/order within categories - Parse RACI assignments with improved error handling **Sample HTML Structure Support** ```html
Contract & Payment Processing
Contract Generation
Generate enrollment agreement...
R: Sales Operations | A: Josh Harris | C: Acquisition Advisor
``` ### 5. Content Synchronization **Visual Diagram Updates** - When RACI activities are modified, update the stored Visual Diagram HTML - Implement sync mechanism to reflect activity changes in visual content - Version control for both RACI and Visual content **Bidirectional Sync** - Changes in RACI tab update Visual Diagram content - Consider future enhancement for Visual Diagram changes updating RACI ### 6. User Experience Enhancements **Import Process** 1. User clicks "Import HTML" button in RACI tab 2. Dialog opens with file upload/paste options 3. HTML is parsed and preview shown (optional enhancement) 4. User confirms import 5. All existing activities are replaced 6. Visual Diagram content is created/updated 7. Success message and page refresh **Error Handling** - Validation for HTML structure - Clear error messages for parsing failures - Rollback mechanism if import fails - Preview mode to validate before final import ### 7. Integration Points **Authorization** - Use existing policy system (`BusinessProcessCore` policies) - Ensure user owns the core process before allowing import **Route Integration** - Leverage existing route patterns - Maintain consistency with current API structure **Type Definitions** - Update TypeScript types for new import functionality - Add interfaces for category-activity relationships ## Files to Modify ### Backend - `app/Traits/HtmlParser.php` - Enhanced parsing logic - `app/Http/Controllers/ProcessCoreController.php` - New import method - `routes/web.php` - Add import route - `database/migrations/` - If needed for category relationships ### Frontend - `resources/js/components/business-processes/business-process-activities-card.tsx` - `resources/js/components/diagrams/html-import-dialog.tsx` - `resources/js/pages/business-processes/cores/partials/visual-tab-content.tsx` - `resources/js/types/index.d.ts` - Type definitions ## Testing Strategy - Unit tests for enhanced HTML parsing - Integration tests for import workflow - Frontend component tests for user interactions - End-to-end tests for complete import process This implementation will provide a seamless HTML import experience while maintaining the existing architecture and adding powerful category-based activity organization.

            $table->id();
            $table->string('name')->unique();
            $table->text('description')->nullable();
            $table->integer('position')->default(0);
            $table->string('color', 7)->nullable(); // hex color
            $table->timestamps();

            // Indexes
            $table->index('position');
        });

        // Create business_process_processes table

            $table->id();
            $table->string('name');
            $table->foreignId('business_process_category_id')
                ->constrained('business_process_categories')
                ->onDelete('cascade');
            $table->text('description')->nullable();
            $table->integer('position')->default(0);
            $table->foreignId('owner_id')->nullable()
                ->constrained('users')
                ->onDelete('set null');
            $table->enum('status', ['draft', 'active', 'archived'])->default('draft');
            $table->timestamps();

            // Indexes
            $table->index('business_process_category_id', 'bpp_category_id_idx');
            $table->index('owner_id', 'bpp_owner_id_idx');
            $table->index(['business_process_category_id', 'position'], 'bpp_category_position_idx');
            $table->index('status', 'bpp_status_idx');
            $table->index('created_at', 'bpp_created_at_idx');
        });

        // Create business_process_cores table (replaces diagrams)
        Schema::create('business_process_cores', function (Blueprint $table) {
            $table->id();
            $table->string('name');
            $table->foreignId('business_process_id')
                ->constrained('business_process_processes')
                ->onDelete('cascade');
            $table->text('description')->nullable();
            $table->integer('position')->default(0);
            $table->string('owner')->nullable();
            $table->foreignId('user_id')
                ->constrained('users')
                ->onDelete('cascade');
            $table->tinyInteger('status')->default(0); // 0=draft, 1=active, 2=archived
            $table->string('version', 50)->default('1.0');
            $table->timestamps();

            // Indexes
            $table->index('business_process_id', 'bpc_process_id_idx');
            $table->index('user_id', 'bpc_user_id_idx');
            $table->index(['business_process_id', 'position'], 'bpc_process_position_idx');
            $table->index(['user_id', 'status'], 'bpc_user_status_idx');
            $table->index('updated_at', 'bpc_updated_at_idx');
        });

        // Create business_process_activities table (RACI structured data)
        Schema::create('business_process_activities', function (Blueprint $table) {
            $table->id();
            $table->foreignId('business_process_core_id')
                ->constrained('business_process_cores')
                ->onDelete('cascade');
            $table->string('name');
            $table->integer('position')->default(0);
            $table->string('responsible')->nullable();
            $table->string('accountable')->nullable();
            $table->string('consulted')->nullable();
            $table->string('informed')->nullable();
            $table->timestamps();

            // Indexes
            $table->index('business_process_core_id', 'bpa_core_id_idx');
            $table->index(['business_process_core_id', 'position'], 'bpa_core_position_idx');
            $table->unique(['business_process_core_id', 'name'], 'bpa_core_name_unique');
        });

        // Create business_process_contents table (SOP, Visual, Swimlane content)
        Schema::create('business_process_contents', function (Blueprint $table) {
            $table->id();
            $table->foreignId('business_process_core_id')
                ->constrained('business_process_cores')
                ->onDelete('cascade');
            $table->enum('type', ['sop', 'visual_diagram', 'swimlane']);
            $table->string('title');
            $table->foreignId('created_by')

            $table->foreignId('updated_by')
                ->constrained('users')
                ->onDelete('cascade');
            $table->boolean('is_archived')->default(false);
            $table->timestamp('archived_date')->nullable();
            $table->foreignId('archived_by')->nullable()
                ->constrained('users')
                ->onDelete('set null');
            $table->timestamps();

            // Indexes
            $table->index('business_process_core_id', 'bpco_core_id_idx');
            $table->index('created_by', 'bpco_created_by_idx');
            $table->index('updated_by', 'bpco_updated_by_idx');
            $table->index(['business_process_core_id', 'type'], 'bpco_core_type_idx');
            $table->index('is_archived', 'bpco_archived_idx');
            $table->index('created_at', 'bpco_created_at_idx');
            $table->unique(['business_process_core_id', 'type'], 'bpco_core_type_unique');
        });

        // Create business_process_content_versions table (unified versioning)
        Schema::create('business_process_content_versions', function (Blueprint $table) {
            $table->id();

                ->onDelete('cascade');

            $table->enum('status', ['draft', 'current', 'archived'])->default('draft');
            $table->text('change_summary')->nullable();
            $table->foreignId('created_by')
                ->constrained('users')
                ->onDelete('cascade');
            $table->foreignId('updated_by')
                ->constrained('users')
                ->onDelete('cascade');
            $table->timestamps();

            // Indexes
            $table->unique('activity_id', 'bpb_activity_id_unique'); // one blueprint per activity
            $table->index('created_by', 'bpb_created_by_idx');
            $table->index('updated_by', 'bpb_updated_by_idx');
            $table->index('status', 'bpb_status_idx');

content.text:
Perfect! Now I understand the architecture much better. You're absolutely right:

1. **Activity Categories**: The `.section-header` elements in the HTML (like "Contract & Payment Processing", "Customer Onboarding & Qualification") are NOT the same as the existing `business_process_categories` table. These are **activity groupings within a single core process**.

2. **Visual Diagram Storage**: The `business_process_contents` table with type `'visual_diagram'` already exists and is perfect for storing the imported HTML content.

Looking at the database schema, I can see that:
- We don't need any new tables or fields for activity categories
- The `business_process_activities` table just needs to store the activity name and RACI data
- The imported HTML can be stored as `visual_diagram` content in the existing content versioning system

# Revised HTML Import Implementation Plan for RACI Tab ## Overview Add "Import HTML" button to RACI tab that parses HTML content, extracts activities with RACI data, replaces existing activities, and stores the HTML as Visual Diagram content using the existing content versioning system. ## Implementation Steps ### 1. Backend Updates **Enhance HtmlParser Trait** (`app/Traits/HtmlParser.php`) - Modify existing `parseHtmlToActivities()` method to handle the new HTML structure - Extract activities from `.step-box` elements within `.process-section` containers - Parse `.section-header` elements for organizational context (but don't store as separate categories) - Extract `.step-title`, `.step-desc`, and `.raci` content - Maintain existing RACI parsing logic but enhance for the new format **Update ProcessCoreController** (`app/Http/Controllers/ProcessCoreController.php`) - Add new method `importHtmlToRaci(Request $request, BusinessProcessProcess $process, BusinessProcessCore $core)` - Logic: 1. Parse HTML using enhanced HtmlParser 2. Delete all existing activities for the core (override functionality) 3. Create new activities with extracted RACI data 4. Store HTML as `visual_diagram` content using existing BusinessProcessContent system 5. Use existing content versioning (BusinessProcessContentVersion) 6. Return JSON response for frontend **Add New Route** (`routes/web.php`) ```php Route::post('/business-processes/{process}/cores/{core}/import-html-raci', [ProcessCoreController::class, 'importHtmlToRaci']) ->name('business-processes.cores.import-html-raci'); ``` ### 2. Frontend Updates **Update BusinessProcessActivitiesCard** (`resources/js/components/business-processes/business-process-activities-card.tsx`) - Add "Import HTML" button next to "Add Activity" button - Add state for import dialog: `const [importDialogOpen, setImportDialogOpen] = useState(false)` - Import and use existing `HtmlImportDialog` component with new props - Pass core process information to dialog **Enhance HtmlImportDialog** (`resources/js/components/diagrams/html-import-dialog.tsx`) - Add new prop: `importType?: 'diagram' | 'raci'` (default 'diagram' for backward compatibility) - Add new prop: `coreId?: number` for RACI imports - Update route calls based on import type: - Legacy: `route('diagrams.parse-html', diagramId)` - RACI: `route('business-processes.cores.import-html-raci', [processId, coreId])` - Update warning text for RACI mode: "This will replace all existing activities in the current RACI matrix" - Update example HTML structure in placeholder **Update VisualTabContent** (`resources/js/pages/business-processes/cores/partials/visual-tab-content.tsx`) - Replace placeholder with real content display - Fetch and display visual diagram content from the core's `visual_diagram` content - Show imported HTML when available - Add basic styling to display the HTML content properly ### 3. Enhanced HTML Parsing Logic **Parse HTML Structure like:** ```html
Contract & Payment Processing
Contract Generation
Generate Accelerator enrollment agreement...
R: Sales Operations | A: Josh Harris | C: Acquisition Advisor
``` **Extraction Logic:** 1. Find all `.step-box` elements 2. For each step-box: - Extract activity name from `.step-title` - Extract description from `.step-desc` (optional) - Extract RACI from `.raci` element - Parse RACI format: "R: Person | A: Person | C: Person | I: Person" 3. Create activities in sequential order with position numbers ### 4. Content Storage Integration **Visual Diagram Content Storage:** - Use existing `BusinessProcessContent` with type `'visual_diagram'` - Store complete HTML as content in `BusinessProcessContentVersion` - Leverage existing versioning system - Set appropriate metadata for import source **Content Synchronization:** - Import creates new visual diagram content version - Future enhancement: when RACI activities change, optionally update visual content ### 5. User Experience Flow **Import Process:** 1. User clicks "Import HTML" in RACI tab 2. Dialog opens (reusing existing HtmlImportDialog) 3. User uploads file or pastes HTML content 4. Backend processes HTML: - Parses activities and RACI data - Deletes existing activities - Creates new activities - Stores HTML as visual diagram content 5. Frontend refreshes RACI matrix 6. Visual tab now shows the imported content 7. Success message displayed **Error Handling:** - Validation for HTML structure - Clear error messages for parsing failures - Transaction rollback if any step fails - Preserve existing data if import fails ### 6. Files to Modify **Backend:** - `app/Traits/HtmlParser.php` - Enhanced parsing for new HTML structure - `app/Http/Controllers/ProcessCoreController.php` - New importHtmlToRaci method - `routes/web.php` - Add new route **Frontend:** - `resources/js/components/business-processes/business-process-activities-card.tsx` - Add import button and dialog - `resources/js/components/diagrams/html-import-dialog.tsx` - Support RACI mode - `resources/js/pages/business-processes/cores/partials/visual-tab-content.tsx` - Display visual content - `resources/js/pages/business-processes/cores/show.tsx` - Pass visual content to tabs **No Database Changes Required:** - Use existing `business_process_activities` table - Use existing `business_process_contents` and `business_process_content_versions` tables - No new fields or tables needed ### 7. Implementation Notes **Activity Categories Handling:** - Section headers like "Contract & Payment Processing" are parsed for context but not stored as separate database entities - They serve as organizational groupings within the single HTML document - Activities are stored sequentially without explicit category relationships **RACI Data Format:** - Store as individual string fields: `responsible`, `accountable`, `consulted`, `informed` - Parse "R: Person | A: Person" format into individual fields - Handle "N/A" values appropriately **Visual Content Integration:** - Imported HTML becomes the visual diagram content - Existing content versioning system handles history - Future sync between RACI changes and visual content is possible enhancement This approach leverages the existing architecture without requiring database schema changes while providing the requested functionality.

Ah, that's a key clarification! So activities can optionally have a category, which means we should add a field to store the activity category. Let me revise the plan accordingly.

Looking at the HTML sample, we have activities grouped under section headers like:
- "Contract & Payment Processing" 
- "Customer Onboarding & Qualification"

- "Transition to Service Delivery"

These would be the activity categories that some activities belong to, while others might not have any category.

input.plan:
# Final HTML Import Implementation Plan for RACI Tab ## Overview Add "Import HTML" button to RACI tab that parses HTML content, extracts activities with optional categories and RACI data, replaces existing activities, and stores the HTML as Visual Diagram content. ## Implementation Steps ### 1. Database Schema Update **Add Activity Category Field** - Add migration to add `category` field to `business_process_activities` table: ```php Schema::table('business_process_activities', function (Blueprint $table) { $table->string('category')->nullable()->after('name'); }); ``` **Update Model** - Add `'category'` to fillable array in `BusinessProcessActivity` model ### 2. Backend Updates **Enhance HtmlParser Trait** (`app/Traits/HtmlParser.php`) - Modify `parseHtmlToActivities()` method to handle new HTML structure - Parse `.process-section` containers to identify category groupings - Extract category name from `.section-header` elements - Associate activities within each section with that category - Parse activities from `.step-box` elements with category context - Extract `.step-title`, `.step-desc`, and `.raci` content - Handle activities without categories (if they exist outside process-section containers) **Enhanced Parsing Logic:** ```php // Pseudocode for parsing structure foreach (process-section containers) { $category = extract text from .section-header foreach (.step-box within this section) { $activity = [ 'category' => $category, 'name' => extract from .step-title, 'description' => extract from .step-desc, 'responsible' => parse from .raci, 'accountable' => parse from .raci, 'consulted' => parse from .raci, 'informed' => parse from .raci, ] } } ``` **Update ProcessCoreController** (`app/Http/Controllers/ProcessCoreController.php`) - Add new method `importHtmlToRaci(Request $request, BusinessProcessProcess $process, BusinessProcessCore $core)` - Logic: 1. Validate HTML content 2. Parse HTML using enhanced HtmlParser to extract activities with categories 3. Delete all existing activities for the core (override functionality) 4. Create new activities with category, RACI data, and sequential positions 5. Store original HTML as `visual_diagram` content using existing BusinessProcessContent system 6. Return JSON response with success/error status **Add New Route** (`routes/web.php`) ```php Route::post('/business-processes/{process}/cores/{core}/import-html-raci', [ProcessCoreController::class, 'importHtmlToRaci']) ->name('business-processes.cores.import-html-raci'); ``` ### 3. Frontend Updates **Update BusinessProcessActivity Type** (`resources/js/types/index.d.ts`) ```typescript export interface BusinessProcessActivity { id: number; name: string; category?: string; // New optional field responsible?: string; accountable?: string; consulted?: string; informed?: string; position: number; // ... other existing fields } ``` **Update BusinessProcessActivitiesCard** (`resources/js/components/business-processes/business-process-activities-card.tsx`) - Add "Import HTML" button next to "Add Activity" button - Add state for import dialog: `const [importDialogOpen, setImportDialogOpen] = useState(false)` - Import and use existing `HtmlImportDialog` component with new props - Update RACI table to show category column (optional, or group activities by category) - Handle category display in activity rows **Enhanced RACI Table Display Options:** Option 1 - Add Category Column: ```typescript Category Activity R // ... other RACI columns ``` Option 2 - Group by Category: ```typescript // Group activities by category and show category headers {groupedActivities.map(([category, activities]) => ( <> {category && {category}} {activities.map(activity => )} ))} ``` **Enhance HtmlImportDialog** (`resources/js/components/diagrams/html-import-dialog.tsx`) - Add new props: `importType?: 'diagram' | 'raci'`, `coreId?: number`, `processId?: number` - Update route calls based on import type: - Legacy: `route('diagrams.parse-html', diagramId)` - RACI: `route('business-processes.cores.import-html-raci', [processId, coreId])` - Update warning text for RACI mode: "This will replace all existing activities and categories in the current RACI matrix" - Update example HTML structure in placeholder to show section-header pattern **Update VisualTabContent** (`resources/js/pages/business-processes/cores/partials/visual-tab-content.tsx`) - Replace placeholder with real content display - Fetch and display visual diagram content from the core's visual_diagram content - Show imported HTML with proper styling - Handle case where no visual content exists ### 4. HTML Structure Support **Expected HTML Structure:** ```html
Contract & Payment Processing
Contract Generation
Generate Accelerator enrollment agreement...
R: Sales Operations | A: Josh Harris | C: Acquisition Advisor
Payment Processing
Process $12,500 payment via Stripe...
R: Sales Operations | A: Josh Harris | C: N/A
``` **Parsing Rules:** 1. Find all `.process-section` containers 2. For each section: - Extract category name from `.section-header` - Find all `.step-box` elements within this section - Each step-box becomes an activity with the section's category 3. Handle `.step-box` elements outside sections (no category) 4. Parse RACI format: "R: Person | A: Person | C: Person | I: Person" 5. Handle "N/A" values appropriately ### 5. User Experience Enhancements **RACI Table Display:** - Show category as first column or use grouped display - Allow activities without categories - Maintain drag-and-drop functionality - Show category in create/edit activity forms **Import Process:** 1. User clicks "Import HTML" in RACI tab 2. Dialog opens with file upload/paste options 3. User uploads file or pastes HTML content 4. Backend processes HTML and creates activities with categories 5. Frontend refreshes RACI matrix showing categorized activities 6. Visual tab shows imported HTML content 7. Success message with count of imported activities and categories ### 6. Files to Modify **Database:** - `database/migrations/YYYY_MM_DD_HHMMSS_add_category_to_business_process_activities.php` - New migration **Backend:** - `app/Models/BusinessProcessActivity.php` - Add category to fillable - `app/Traits/HtmlParser.php` - Enhanced parsing with category extraction - `app/Http/Controllers/ProcessCoreController.php` - New importHtmlToRaci method - `routes/web.php` - Add new route **Frontend:** - `resources/js/types/index.d.ts` - Add category field to types - `resources/js/components/business-processes/business-process-activities-card.tsx` - Add import button, handle categories - `resources/js/components/diagrams/html-import-dialog.tsx` - Support RACI mode - `resources/js/pages/business-processes/cores/partials/visual-tab-content.tsx` - Display visual content ### 7. Implementation Details **Category Handling:** - Categories are strings extracted from section headers - Activities can have null/empty category (not required) - No separate category table - just a string field on activities - Categories are contextual to each core process **RACI Data Storage:** - Store as individual string fields: `responsible`, `accountable`, `consulted`, `informed` - Parse "R: Person | A: Person" format into individual fields - Handle "N/A" and empty values as null **Visual Content Integration:** - Store complete original HTML as visual_diagram content - Use existing BusinessProcessContent versioning system - Visual tab displays the raw imported HTML with styling **Data Migration:** - Migration adds nullable category field - Existing activities get null category by default - No data loss during upgrade This approach adds the minimal database change needed while providing full category support for activities imported from HTML.

message.content: Just checking, and work with me on this one as a co-developer, the new category should be a field or a table and use relationships?

content.text:
Great question! Let me think through this with you as a co-developer. We have a few options to consider:

## Option 1: Simple String Field
```php
// business_process_activities table
$table->string('category')->nullable();
```

**Pros:**
- Simple and fast to implement
- No additional queries needed
- Categories are contextual to each core process
- Good for unique/one-off category names per import

**Cons:**
- No reusability across different cores
- Potential for typos/inconsistency
- Can't easily query "all activities in X category across all cores"
- No metadata about categories (colors, descriptions, etc.)

## Option 2: Separate Activity Categories Table
```php
// activity_categories table
id, name, description, color, created_at, updated_at

// business_process_activities table  
$table->foreignId('activity_category_id')->nullable()->constrained('activity_categories');
```

**Pros:**
- Reusable across different cores
- Can add metadata (colors, descriptions)
- Referential integrity
- Better for analytics/reporting
- Can easily find all activities of a specific category type

**Cons:**
- More complex implementation
- Need to handle category creation during import
- Additional JOIN queries
- Might be overkill if categories are very specific to each HTML import

## Option 3: Hybrid - Core-Scoped Categories
```php
// activity_categories table
id, business_process_core_id, name, description, position, created_at, updated_at

// business_process_activities table
$table->foreignId('activity_category_id')->nullable()->constrained('activity_categories');
```

**Pros:**
- Categories scoped to each core process
- Still normalized and extensible
- Can reorder categories within a core
- Can add colors/styling per category
- Better data structure for UI grouping

**Cons:**
- Most complex to implement
- Categories don't cross core boundaries

## My Recommendation

Looking at the HTML sample and use case, I'm leaning toward **Option 1 (simple string field)** for these reasons:

1. **Import Context**: Categories like "Contract & Payment Processing" seem very specific to this particular business process import
2. **Simplicity**: We want to get this working quickly without overengineering
3. **Flexibility**: Different HTML imports might have completely different category structures
4. **Core-Specific**: These categories are really about organizing activities within one specific core process

However, if you think users might want to:
- Reuse category names across different core processes
- Add colors or styling to categories
- Do analytics across category types
- Have a more structured approach

Then **Option 3** might be worth the extra complexity.

What's your gut feeling? Are these categories likely to be:
- Very specific to each imported HTML document? (â†’ String field)
- Reusable patterns that users might want across processes? (â†’ Separate table)

message.content: I think I would like to go with option 3

content.thinking:
Great choice! Option 3 (Core-Scoped Categories) gives us the best of both worlds - proper normalization and relationships while keeping categories scoped to each core process. This will allow for better organization, potential UI enhancements like colors/styling, and proper data structure.

Let me think through the implementation:

1. We'll need a new `business_process_activity_categories` table
2. It will be scoped to each core process 
3. Activities will have a foreign key to this category table
4. During HTML import, we'll:
   - Parse section headers as categories
   - Create categories for the core if they don't exist
   - Associate activities with their categories
5. This opens up future possibilities like:
   - Drag and drop reordering of categories
   - Color coding categories
   - Collapsible category sections in the UI
   - Analytics by category

This is definitely the more robust approach and will scale better.

content.text: Perfect choice! Option 3 gives us the best of both worlds - proper normalization while keeping categories scoped to each core process. This will enable some nice future enhancements too.

    public function up(): void
    {
        Schema::create('business_process_activity_categories', function (Blueprint $table) {
            $table->id();
            $table->foreignId('business_process_core_id')
                ->constrained('business_process_cores')
                ->onDelete('cascade');
            $table->string('name');
            $table->text('description')->nullable();
            $table->integer('position')->default(0);
            $table->string('color', 7)->nullable(); // hex color for UI

            // Indexes

            $table->index(['business_process_core_id', 'position'], 'bpac_core_position_idx');
            $table->unique(['business_process_core_id', 'name'], 'bpac_core_name_unique');
        });
    }

    /**
     * Reverse the migrations.
     */
    public function down(): void
    {
        Schema::dropIfExists('business_process_activity_categories');
    }
};

<?php

namespace App\Models;

use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Factories\HasFactory;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Model;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Relations\BelongsTo;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Relations\HasMany;

class BusinessProcessActivityCategory extends Model
{
    use HasFactory;

    protected $fillable = [
        'business_process_core_id',
        'name', 
        'description',
        'position',
        'color'
    ];

    protected $casts = [
        'business_process_core_id' => 'integer',
        'position' => 'integer',
        'created_at' => 'datetime:M j, Y - H:i:s',
        'updated_at' => 'datetime:M j, Y - H:i:s',
    ];

    public function core(): BelongsTo
    {
        return $this->belongsTo(BusinessProcessCore::class, 'business_process_core_id');
    }
    
    public function activities(): HasMany 
    {
        return $this->hasMany(BusinessProcessActivity::class, 'activity_category_id')
            ->orderBy('position');
    }
}

<?php

namespace App\Models;

use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Factories\HasFactory;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Model;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Relations\BelongsTo;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Relations\HasMany;

class BusinessProcessCore extends Model
{
    use HasFactory;

    protected $fillable = [
        'name',
        'business_process_id',
        'description',
        'position',
        'owner',
        'user_id',
        'status',
        'version'
    ];

    protected $casts = [
        'position' => 'integer',
        'business_process_id' => 'integer',
        'user_id' => 'integer',
        'status' => 'integer',
        'created_at' => 'datetime:M j, Y - H:i:s',
        'updated_at' => 'datetime:M j, Y - H:i:s',
    ];

    public function process(): BelongsTo
    {
        return $this->belongsTo(BusinessProcessProcess::class, 'business_process_id');
    }

    public function user(): BelongsTo
    {
        return $this->belongsTo(User::class);
    }

    public function activities(): HasMany
    {
        return $this->hasMany(BusinessProcessActivity::class, 'business_process_core_id');
    }

    public function contents(): HasMany
    {
        return $this->hasMany(BusinessProcessContent::class, 'business_process_core_id');
    }

    // Helper methods for different content types
    public function sopContent()
    {
        return $this->contents()->where('type', 'sop')->first();
    }

    public function visualContent()
    {
        return $this->contents()->where('type', 'visual_diagram')->first();
    }

    public function swimlaneContent()
    {
        return $this->contents()->where('type', 'swimlane')->first();
    }
}

## 3. Enhanced HTML Parser

Now let's enhance the HtmlParser trait to handle category parsing:

file.content:
<?php

namespace App\Traits;

use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Log;
use DOMDocument;
use DOMXPath;

trait HtmlParser
{
    /**
     * Parses HTML content to extract a list of activities with their RACI assignments.
     *
     * @param string $htmlContent The HTML content to parse.
     * @return array A list of activities, where each activity is an associative array.
     *               Example structure:
     *               [
     *                   'name' => 'Activity Name',
     *                   'position' => 1,
     *                   'current_future' => 0, // 0 for Current, 1 for Future
     *                   'responsible' => 'Person R',
     *                   'accountable' => 'Person A',
     *                   'consulted' => 'Person C',
     *                   'informed' => 'Person I',
     *                   'process_link' => null,
     *                   'description' => null,
     *                   'type' => null,
     *               ]
     */
    public function parseHtmlToActivities(string $htmlContent): array
    {
        Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Starting HTML parsing');

        $activities = [];
        $position = 0;

        // Create a DOMDocument and load the HTML
        $dom = new DOMDocument();

        // Suppress warnings for malformed HTML
        libxml_use_internal_errors(true);

        // Load HTML content
        $dom->loadHTML($htmlContent, LIBXML_HTML_NOIMPLIED | LIBXML_HTML_NODEFDTD);

        // Clear libxml errors
        libxml_clear_errors();

        $xpath = new DOMXPath($dom);

        // Find all step-box elements (activities)
        $stepBoxes = $xpath->query("//div[contains(@class, 'step-box')]");

        Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Found step boxes', ['count' => $stepBoxes->length]);

        foreach ($stepBoxes as $stepBox) {
            $position++;

            // Extract activity name from step-title
            $titleNodes = $xpath->query(".//div[contains(@class, 'step-title')]", $stepBox);
            $activityName = $titleNodes->length > 0 ? trim($titleNodes->item(0)->textContent) : '';

            // Extract description from step-desc
            $descNodes = $xpath->query(".//div[contains(@class, 'step-desc')]", $stepBox);
            $description = $descNodes->length > 0 ? trim($descNodes->item(0)->textContent) : null;

            // Extract RACI information from raci class
            $raciNodes = $xpath->query(".//div[contains(@class, 'raci')]", $stepBox);
            $raciText = $raciNodes->length > 0 ? trim($raciNodes->item(0)->textContent) : '';

            Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Processing activity', [
                'position' => $position,
                'name' => $activityName,
                'description' => $description,
                'raci_text' => $raciText
            ]);

            // Skip if no activity name
            if (empty($activityName)) {
                Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Skipping activity with empty name');
                continue;
            }

            // Initialize activity data
            $activityData = [
                'name' => $activityName,
                'position' => $position,
                'current_future' => 0, // Default to current
                'responsible' => null,
                'accountable' => null,
                'consulted' => null,
                'informed' => null,
                'process_link' => null,
                'description' => $description,
                'type' => null,
            ];

            // Parse RACI information
            if (!empty($raciText)) {
                $activityData = $this->parseRaciFromText($raciText, $activityData);
            }

            Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Final activity data', ['data' => $activityData]);
            $activities[] = $activityData;
        }

        Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Parsing complete. Total activities parsed:', ['count' => count($activities)]);
        return $activities;
    }

    /**
     * Parse RACI information from text like "R: Julia | A: Vipul | C: Dale"
     *
     * @param string $raciText The RACI text to parse
     * @param array $activityData The activity data array to update
     * @return array Updated activity data with RACI assignments
     */
    private function parseRaciFromText(string $raciText, array $activityData): array
    {
        Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Parsing RACI text', ['text' => $raciText]);

        // Handle special case for handoff text
        if (strpos($raciText, 'Handoff to') !== false) {
            Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Skipping handoff text');
            return $activityData;
        }

        // Split by pipe (|) to get individual RACI assignments
        $raciParts = explode('|', $raciText);

        foreach ($raciParts as $part) {
            $part = trim($part);

            // Match pattern like "R: Julia" or "A: Vipul"
            if (preg_match('/^([RACI])\s*:\s*(.+)$/i', $part, $matches)) {
                $role = strtoupper(trim($matches[1]));
                $person = trim($matches[2]);

                // Skip N/A assignments
                if (strtoupper($person) === 'N/A') {
                    continue;
                }

                Log::debug('[HtmlParser] Found RACI assignment', ['role' => $role, 'person' => $person]);

                switch ($role) {
                    case 'R':
                        $activityData['responsible'] = $person;
                        break;
                    case 'A':
                        $activityData['accountable'] = $person;
                        break;
                    case 'C':
                        $activityData['consulted'] = $person;
                        break;
                    case 'I':
                        $activityData['informed'] = $person;
                        break;
                }
            }
        }

        return $activityData;
    }
}

<?php

namespace App\Http\Controllers;

use App\Models\BusinessProcessProcess;
use App\Models\BusinessProcessCore;
use App\Models\BusinessProcessActivity;
use App\Traits\HtmlParser;
use Illuminate\Http\Request;
use Inertia\Inertia;
use Inertia\Response;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Auth;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\DB;
use Illuminate\Http\RedirectResponse;
use Illuminate\Support\Facades\Log;
use Illuminate\Foundation\Auth\Access\AuthorizesRequests;

class ProcessCoreController extends Controller
{
    use HtmlParser, AuthorizesRequests;

    public function index(BusinessProcessProcess $process): Response
    {
        // Eager load the category for breadcrumbs
        $process->load('category');

        // Retrieve cores related to the specific process
        // and belonging to the authenticated user, then paginate.
        $cores = $process->cores() // Access the HasMany relationship
            ->where('user_id', Auth::id()) // Filter by the current user
            ->withCount('activities') // Add activities count
            ->orderBy('updated_at', 'desc')
            ->paginate(10);

        // Transform cores to diagrams for frontend compatibility
        $cores->getCollection()->transform(function ($core) {
            $coreArray = $core->toArray();
            return $coreArray;
        });

        // The $process model instance is already available.
        // We pass the filtered and paginated $cores to the view.
        return Inertia::render('business-processes/cores/index', [
            'process' => $process,
            'cores' => $cores,
        ]);
    }

    public function store(Request $request, BusinessProcessProcess $process): RedirectResponse
    {
        // Check if user can create cores
        $this->authorize('create', BusinessProcessCore::class);

        $validatedData = $request->validate([
            'name' => 'required|string|max:255',
            'description' => 'nullable|string',
            'version' => 'nullable|string|max:10',
        ]);

        $core = $process->cores()->create([
            'name' => $validatedData['name'],
            'description' => $validatedData['description'],
            'version' => $validatedData['version'] ?? '1.0',
            'owner' => Auth::user()->name, // Set authenticated user as owner
            'status' => 0,     // Default status (e.g., Draft)
            'user_id' => Auth::id()
        ]);

        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$process->id, $core->id])->with('success', 'Core created successfully.');
    }

    public function show(Request $request, BusinessProcessCore $core): Response
    {
        // Check if user can view this core
        $this->authorize('view', $core);

        // Eager load the process, user, and category relationships
        $core->load(['process.category', 'user']);

        // Paginate activities (50 per page) ordered by position
        // Include Blueprint relationships for activity integration with optimized queries
        $activities = $core->activities()
            ->with(['blueprint'])
            ->orderBy('position')
            ->paginate(50);

        // Generate Mermaid code from all activities (not paginated for visualization)
        // Cache the Mermaid code for better performance
        $cacheKey = "core_mermaid_{$core->id}_{$core->updated_at->timestamp}";
        $generatedMermaidCode = cache()->remember($cacheKey, 3600, function () use ($core) {
            // For now, return empty string - can implement mermaid generation later
            return '';
        });

        // Transform core to diagram for frontend compatibility
        $coreArray = $core->toArray();

        return Inertia::render('business-processes/cores/show', [
            'core' => $coreArray,
            'activities' => $activities,
            'generatedMermaidCode' => $generatedMermaidCode,
        ]);
    }

    public function update(Request $request, BusinessProcessCore $core): RedirectResponse
    {
        // Check if user can update this core
        $this->authorize('update', $core);

        $validatedData = $request->validate([
            'name' => 'required|string|max:255',
            'description' => 'nullable|string',
            'owner' => 'required|string|max:255',
            'status' => 'required|integer|in:0,1,2', // Assuming 0: Draft, 1: Active, 2: Archived
        ]);

        $core->update($validatedData);

        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$core->process->id, $core->id])->with('success', 'Core updated successfully.');
    }

    public function destroy(BusinessProcessCore $core): RedirectResponse
    {
        // Check if user can delete this core
        $this->authorize('delete', $core);

        $processId = $core->business_process_id;
        $coreName = $core->name;

        // Delete the core (activities will be cascade deleted due to foreign key constraint)
        $core->delete();

        // Redirect back to the process cores index with success message
        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.index', $processId)
            ->with('success', 'Core "' . $coreName . '" and all its activities have been deleted successfully.');
    }

    public function storeActivity(Request $request, BusinessProcessProcess $process, BusinessProcessCore $core): RedirectResponse
    {
        if ($core->business_process_id !== $process->id) {
            abort(404); // Or handle as a validation error
        }

        // Check if user can view/modify this core (implicitly allows creating activities)
        $this->authorize('update', $core);

        // Check for duplicate activity name first
        $existingActivity = $core->activities()->where('name', $request->input('name'))->first();
        if ($existingActivity) {
            return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$process->id, $core->id])
                ->with('error', 'An activity with this name already exists in this core. Please choose a different name.');
        }

        $validated = $request->validate([
            'name' => 'required|string|max:255',
            'responsible' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'accountable' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'consulted' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'informed' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
        ]);

        $maxPosition = $core->activities()->max('position');
        $newPosition = ($maxPosition === null) ? 1 : $maxPosition + 1;

        $activityData = $validated + [
            'position' => $newPosition,
        ];

        $core->activities()->create($activityData);

        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$process->id, $core->id])->with('success', 'Activity created successfully.');
    }

    // New method to update an existing activity
    public function updateActivity(Request $request, BusinessProcessActivity $activity): RedirectResponse
    {
        // Load the core relationship and check authorization
        $activity->load('core');
        $this->authorize('update', $activity);

        // Check for duplicate activity name first (excluding current activity)
        $existingActivity = $activity->core->activities()
            ->where('name', $request->input('name'))
            ->where('id', '!=', $activity->id)
            ->first();

        if ($existingActivity) {
            return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$activity->core->process->id, $activity->core->id])
                ->with('error', 'An activity with this name already exists in this core. Please choose a different name.');
        }

        $validatedData = $request->validate([
            'name' => 'required|string|max:255',
            'responsible' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'accountable' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'consulted' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
            'informed' => 'nullable|string|max:255',
        ]);

        $activity->update($validatedData);

        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$activity->core->process->id, $activity->core->id])->with('success', 'Activity updated successfully.');
    }

    public function deleteActivity(BusinessProcessActivity $activity): RedirectResponse
    {
        // Load the core relationship and check authorization
        $activity->load('core');
        $this->authorize('delete', $activity);

        $coreId = $activity->business_process_core_id;
        $processId = $activity->core->business_process_id;
        $activityName = $activity->name;

        $activity->delete();

        return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$processId, $coreId])
            ->with('success', 'Activity "' . $activityName . '" has been deleted successfully.');
    }

    public function reorderActivities(Request $request, BusinessProcessProcess $process, BusinessProcessCore $core): RedirectResponse
    {
        $this->authorize('update', $core);

        $validated = $request->validate([
            'activities' => 'required|array',
            'activities.*.id' => 'required|exists:business_process_activities,id',
            'activities.*.order' => 'required|integer|min:1', // Accept 'order' for compatibility with ProcessActivitiesCard
        ]);

        try {
            DB::transaction(function () use ($validated, $core) {
                foreach ($validated['activities'] as $activityData) {
                    // Verify that the activity belongs to this core
                    $activity = $core->activities()
                        ->where('id', $activityData['id'])
                        ->first();

                    if ($activity) {
                        $activity->update(['position' => $activityData['order']]); // Map 'order' to 'position'
                    }
                }
            });

            Log::info('Activities reordered successfully for core ID: ' . $core->id, [
                'core_id' => $core->id,
                'user_id' => Auth::id(),
                'reordered_activities' => $validated['activities'],
            ]);

            return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$core->process->id, $core->id])
                ->with('success', 'Activities reordered successfully.');
        } catch (\Exception $e) {
            Log::error('Failed to reorder activities for core ID: ' . $core->id, [
                'error' => $e->getMessage(),
                'trace' => $e->getTraceAsString(),
                'user_id' => Auth::id(),
            ]);

            return redirect()->route('business-processes.cores.show', [$core->process->id, $core->id])
                ->with('error', 'Failed to reorder activities. Please try again.');
        }
    }
}
